front.title: Identifier: A Link Relation to Convey a Preferred URI for Referencing

abstract.t: This specification defines a link relation type that is intended to convey that a URI, other than the URI that provides a link with the relation type, is preferred for the purpose of referencing.

note.title: Note to Readers
note.t: Please discuss this draft on the ART mailing list ().

section.title: Introduction
section.t: A web resource is routinely referenced (e.g. linked, bookmarked) by means of the URI where it is directly accessed. But cases exist whereby referencing a resource by means of a different URI is preferred, for example because the latter URI is intended to be more persistent over time. Currently, there is no way to convey such alternative referencing preferences; this specification introduces a link relation type intended for that purpose.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .
This section introduces two types of URIs for a web resource:

list.t: "actual URI": An actionable URI at which a user agent accesses a web resource.
"identifying URI": An actionable URI, other than the actual URI, that should preferentially be used for referencing (e.g. linking, bookmarking).

section.t: Here "actionable" means that protocol-based read access to the resource identified by the URI is possible. For example, an HTTP URI is actionable because read access is possible by issuing an HTTP HEAD or GET request against the URI.

section.title: Persistent Identifiers
section.t: Despite sound advice regarding the design of Cool URIs , link rot ("HTTP 404 Not Found") is a common phenomena when following links on the web. Certain communities of practice have introduced a solution to combat this problem that typically consists of:

list.t: Accepting the reality that the web location of a resource - the actual URI - may change over time.
Minting an additional URI for the resource - the identififying URI - that is specifically intended to remain persistent over time.
Redirecting (typically "HTTP 301 Moved Permanently", "HTTP 302 Found", or "HTTP 303 See Other") from the identififying URI to the actual URI.
As a community, committing to adjust that redirection whenever the actual URI changes over time.

section.t: This approach is, for example, used by:

list.t: Scholalry publishers that use DOIs to identify articles and DOI URLs as a means to keep cross-publisher article-to-article links operational, even when the journals in which the articles are published change hands from one publisher to another, for example, as a result of an acquisition.
Authors of controlled vocabularies that use PURLs for vocabulary terms to ensure that the term URIs remain stable even if management of the vocabulary is transfered to a new custodian.
A variety of organizations, including libraries, archives, and museums that assign ARK URLs to information objects in order to support long-term access.

section.t: In order for the investments in infrastructure involved in these approaches to pay off, and hence for links to effectively to remain operational as intended, it is crucial that a resource be referenced by means of its identifying URI. However, the actual URI is where a user agent actually accesses the resource (e.g. it is the URI in the browser's address bar). As such, there is a considerable risk that the actual URI instead of the identifying URI is used for referencing .

The link relation type defined in this specification allows to convey to user agents that the identifying URI is the preferred URI for referencing. Applications such as bookmarking tools, citation managers, and webometrics can take this preference into account when recording a URI.

section.title: Preferred Social Identifier
section.t: A web user commonly has mutliple profiles on the web, for example, one per social network she takes part in, a personal homepage, a professional homepage, a FOAF profile , etc. Each of these profiles is accessible at a distinct URI. But the user may have a preference for one of those profiles, for example, because it is most complete, kept up-to-date, or expected to be long-lived.

The link relation type defined in this specification allows to convey to user agents that a profile URI - the identifying URI - other than the one the agent is accessing - the actual URI - is preferred for referencing.

section.title: Multi-Resource Publications
section.t: When publishing on the web, it is not uncommon to make distinct components of a publication available as different web resources, each with their own URI. For example:

list.t: Contemporary scholarly publications routinely consists of a traditional article as well as additional materials that are considered an integral part of the publication such as supplementary information, high-resolution images, a video recording of an experiment.
Scientific or governmental open data sets frequently consist of multiple files.
Online books typically consist of multiple chapters.

section.t: While each of these components are accessible at their distinct URI - the actual URI - they often also share a URI assinged to the intellectual publication of which they are components - the identifying URI.

The link relation type defined in this specification allows to convey to user agents that, for the purpose of referencing, the identifying URI of the intellectual publication is preferred over an actual URI of a component of the publication.

section.title: The "identifier" Relation Type for Expressing a Preferred URI for the Purpose of Referencing
section.t: A link with the "identifier" relation type indicates that the Target IRI - the identifying URI - is preferred over the Context IRI - the actual URI - for the purpose of referencing.
Because a link with the "identifier" relation type expresses a preferred URI for the purpose of referencing, the actual URI SHOULD only provide one link with that relation type.

Providing a link with the "identifier" relation type does not prevent using the actual URI for the purpose of referencing if such specificity is needed for the application at hand. For example, in the case of scenario the actual URI is likely required for the purpose of annotating a specific component of an intellectual publication. Yet, the annotation application may also want to include a reference to the identifying URI.

section.title: Distinction with Other Relation Types
section.t: The following existing IANA-registered relationships are similar to the relationship that "identifier" is intended to convey, but are not appropriate for various reasons:

list.t: "alternate" , used to link to an alternate version of the content at the Context IRI, for example the same content with varying Content-Type (e.g., application/pdf vs. text/html) and/or Content-Language (e.g., en vs. fr).
"bookmark" , used to convey a permanent link to use for bookmarking purposes.

"canonical" , used to identify content that is either duplicative or a superset of the content at the Context IRI, for example a single page version of a magazine article, provided for indexing by search engines, of an article that is spread over several pages for human use.

"duplicate" , used to link to a resource whose available representations are byte-for-byte identical with the corresponding representations of the context IRI, for example, an identical file on a mirror site.
"related" , used to link to a related resource.

section.t: A closer inspection of these candidates shows that they are not appropriate and that a new relation type is required.

In the scenario of there is no content available at the identifying URI as it merely redirects to the actual URI. In the scenario of , the content at the identifying URI is a profile that is different than the profile at the actual URI. In scenario of the content at the identifying URI, if any, would typcially be a sort of table of contents page with links to component resources and possibly a summary. These considerations exclude "alternate", "canonical", and "duplicate" as possible relation types.

The intent of "bookmark" is closest related to that of "identifier" in that the Target IRI of a link with this relation type is intended for bookmarking, which is a case of referencing. However, "bookmark" is specifically defined for use in conjunction with the HTML <article> element and is explictly excluded from use in the <link> element in HTML <head>. Since a link in <link> and one in the HTTP Link header are semantically equivalent, "bookmark" is also excluded from use in HTTP Link.
While "related" could be used, its semantics are too vague to convey the specific nature of "identifier" as a means to convey a URI for the purpose of referencing.

section.title: Examples
section.t:
Sections and
show examples of the use of links with the "identifier" relation type. One example shows its use in a response header and body, the other in a response body only.

section.title: Persistent HTTP URI
section.t: If the context resource is a landing page for a scholarly article for which the persistent HTTP URI <http://persistence.example.org/738207472> was minted, then the response to an HTTP GET on the landing page's URI could be as shown in .

figure.title: Response to HTTP GET on the URI of the landing page of a scholarly article
figure.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Link: <http://persistence.example.org/738207472> ; rel="identifier" Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8
<html> <head> ... <link rel="identifier" href="http://persistence.example.org/738207472" /> ... </head> <body> ... </body> </html>

section.title: Preferred Profile URI
section.t: If the context resource is the home page of John Doe, John can add a link with the "identifier" relation type to it, as a means to convey that he would preferably be referenced by means of the URI of his FOAF profile. shows the response to an HTTP GET on the URI of John's home page.

figure.title: Response to HTTP GET on the URI of John Doe's home page
figure.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8
<html> <head> ... <link rel="identifier" href="http://johndoe.example.com/foaf" type="txt/ttl"/> ... </head> <body> ... </body> </html>

section.title: Link Relation Type: identifier
section.t: The link relation type below has been registered by IANA per Section 6.2.1 of :

list.t: Relation Name: identifier
Description: A link with the "identifier" relation type that points from a Context IRI to a target IRI indicates that the Target IRI is preferred over the Context IRI for the purpose of referencing.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: There are no additional security concerns introduced by this document.
